intro: Lepidaploa virentiformis, commonly known as the green-leafed lichen, is a unique species characterized by its foliose growth form and vibrant greenish coloration. It belongs to the family Lecanoraceae and is primarily found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky crevices. The plant exhibits a complex thallus structure with distinct upper and lower layers, which aid in photosynthesis and water retention. It forms symbiotic associations with cyanobacteria, contributing to its ability to thrive in nutrient-poor substrates. Due to its specialized habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species in certain regions.
